content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements if not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 allow group health plans to negotiate separate reimbursement rates and manage benefits through mechanisms like pre-admission screening. It does not require specific mental health benefits or prevent plans from applying subsections without regard to preventive care. Effective on the date of enactment, coordination in implementation is amended to include specific provisions from different acts. SEC. 3. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY BENEFITS. This section amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to ensure parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits in group health plans. It also amends the Public Health Service Act to include similar provisions for health insurance issuers. SEC. 2706 and SEC. 9813 ensure parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits, similar to mental health benefits, in group health plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 2753 ensures parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits in individual health insurance coverage under the Public Health Service Act. The provisions of section 2752 apply to substance abuse and chemical dependency treatment benefits in the same way as mental health benefits. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment date. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to individual health insurance coverage in the market starting July 1, 1999, with exceptions for collective bargaining agreements related to plan terminations.
